teaser: International CES has wrapped, but there are still stories to tell. For instance how the startup Veveo's schedule got even more jam packed with clients for its predictive software at the annual event, and how bad chip maker Qualcomm's keynote presentation really was in the final judgment. Also, MIT has invented a new process of bending light on a computer chip, which means we're a step closer to hologram televisions, biomedical imaging, and predictive or autonomous driving.
title: Marketplace Tech for Friday, January 11, 2013
description: International CES has wrapped, but there are still stories to tell. For instance how the startup Veveo's schedule got even more jam packed with clients for its predictive software at the annual event, and how bad chip maker Qualcomm's keynote presentation really was in the final judgment. Also, MIT has invented a new process of bending light on a computer chip, which means we're a step closer to hologram televisions, biomedical imaging, and predictive or autonomous driving.
